title: Thousands of older people are missing out on council-funded adult social care
text:
Fewer vulnerable elderly people are receiving state-provided social care - despite soaring demand.

Figures published yesterday by NHS Digital showed the numbers of over-65s receiving long-term care from councils dropped by 39,000 between 2015/16 and 2018/19.

Yet local authorities received 1.9million requests for adult social care from new clients in 2018/19 - the equivalent of 5,245 requests for support each day.

Figures published yesterday by NHS Digital showed the numbers of over-65s receiving long-term care from councils dropped by 39,000 between 2015/16 and 2018/19 (file photo)

This is an increase of 3.8 per cent since 2017/18 - an extra 195 requests each day.

The Daily Mail is campaigning for a major overhaul of Britain's broken social care system, particularly for the hundreds of thousands of people with dementia, who make up two thirds of those in care.

Boris Johnson has promised to act to fix the system - but has yet to publish any proposals.

The report said the average cost of residential care for a person aged 65 or over rose from £604 per week in 2017/18 to £636 in 2018/19, while the average cost of nursing care for this age group also rose, from £638 per week to £678.

Local authority spending on adult social care rose to £18.7 billion in 2018/19 - a real-terms increase of 2.6 per cent.

The Mail revealed last month that more than 400 elderly people are forced to sell their homes every week to pay for care.

Yet local authorities received 1.9million requests for adult social care from new clients in 2018/19 - the equivalent of 5,245 requests for support each day (file photo)

Claudia Martinez, from the Reform think-tank, said: 'The demand of council care services is rising and we have yet to see anything from the Government that resembles a sensible, sustainable solution to this perennial crisis.

'We need a long-term solution.'

Broadcaster Joan Bakewell no sector was 'crying out for reform more' than the care of the elderly.

Talking in the House of Lords yesterday, Lady Bakewell said: 'Will the Government address these concerns with the greatest urgency and can they give us a timescale?'

authors: Ben Spencer Medical Correspondent For The Daily Mail
